What is vaginal discharge?

Vaginal discharge is a clear, white or off-white fluid that comes out through your vagina. This discharge is produced by your uterus, cervix, and vagina, which consists mainly of cells and bacteria. It helps to clean and lubricate your vagina and helps fight against bad bacteria and infections. Vaginal discharge is a natural and normal process in your body and vaginal discharge is caused due to normal or abnormal reasons.

However, changes in discharge can indicate an infection or disease. Some women produce more vaginal secretions than others, while others notice very little discharge. Changes in the colour, texture, odour, or amount of your usual vaginal discharge could indicate a problem. You can use medications to treat most causes of abnormal vaginal discharge.1 

What are the vaginal discharge causes?

Vaginal discharge is a healthy bodily function caused by natural changes in estrogen levels. The amount of vaginal liquid can increase due to ovulation, sexual arousal, birth control pills and pregnancy.

Changes in the bacterial balance of the vagina can have an adverse impact on the colour, smell, and texture of vaginal fluid discharge in females. This is because vaginal infections are more likely to occur as the number of harmful bacteria increases.

Here are some of the infections that could be the reasons for vaginal discharge:

  • Bacterial Vaginosis – 

Bacterial vaginosis is a common bacterial infection causing an increased vaginal discharge with a strong, foul, and occasionally fishy odour. The vaginal discharge may appear grey, thin, and watery as well. In some cases, this infection does not have any symptoms.

Bacterial vaginosis is not transmitted from one person to another through sexual contact, but you are more likely to develop it if you are sexually active or have recently gotten a new sexual partner. This infection can also increase your chances of developing a sexually transmitted infection (STI).

  • Trichomoniasis – 

Trichomoniasis is another type of parasitic infection. It is usually spread from one person to another through sexual contact, you can also get it through the sharing of towels or bathing suits.

Up to half of those affected with trichomoniasis will experience no symptoms. Those who do will frequently notice a yellow, green, or frothy discharge with a foul odour. Common symptoms include pain, inflammation, and itching around the vagina and when urinating or having sex.

  • Yeast Infection – 

A yeast infection happens when yeast growth in the vagina increases. It creates a thick, white discharge that looks like cottage cheese, and this discharge is usually odourless.

Other symptoms include burning, itching, irritation around the vagina, and also causes pain during sex or urination.

The following factors can increase your risk of yeast infections:

  • Stress
  • Diabetes
  • Using birth control pills
  • Pregnancy
  • Antibiotics (if used for more than ten days)

  • Gonorrhea and Chlamydia – 

Gonorrhea and Chlamydia are STIs that can cause an abnormal discharge by infecting the cervix. It is usually yellow, greenish, or cloudy in appearance.

You may also experience other symptoms like:

  • Pain while urinating
  • Stomach pain
  • Bleeding after penetrative sex
  • Bleeding between periods

But some people may also have zero symptoms.

  • Genital Herpes – 

This STI can cause thick vaginal discharge with a strong odour, especially after having sex. Sores and blisters around the genitals can appear, as can bleeding between periods and a burning sensation when urinating.

However, it is more common to have no or minor symptoms. But if you do develop symptoms, you may have repeated outbreaks throughout your life.

  • Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) – 

Heavy, foul-smelling discharge, stomach pain after sex or while menstruating, and urinating may be symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease.

This occurs when bacteria enter the vagina and travel to other reproductive organs, and it can be caused by untreated STIs such as chlamydia or gonorrhea.

  • Human Papillomavirus (HPV) or Cervical Cancer – 

The human papillomavirus infection is spread through sexual intercourse and can lead to cervical cancer. Even though there may be no symptoms, this type of cancer can cause:

  • Bloody, brown or watery discharge having an unpleasant odour
  • Bleeding occuring between periods or after sex
  • Pain while urinating or an increased urge to pee

In rare instances, brown or bloody discharge can also be an indication of endometrial cancer, fibroids, or other growths.2

What are the five types of discharge?

The different types of vaginal discharge and the colour of your vaginal discharge may indicate a problem.

  • Yellow, green or grey colour – A yellow, grey, or green discharge may indicate that you have a bacterial or sexually transmitted infection (STI).

  • Brown or red colour – A brown or red discharge is generally associated with irregular periods or pregnancy (implantation bleeding). If you experience brown or red-tinged discharge and it is not your period, this could indicate a problem.

  • Clear or white colour – Vaginal discharge is often clear, white, or off-white. If your vaginal discharge is white but thicker than usual or causes itching, you may have a yeast infection.

If your vaginal discharge changes colour or texture or is accompanied by other symptoms such as odour, irritation, or burning, you should contact your doctor. How can I stop so much discharge?

It’s not always an infection that causes vaginal discharge. So, why do women experience vaginal discharge? Vaginal discharge can also be due to changes in the regular balance of healthy bacteria in your vagina and sexual excitement causing vagina leaking. You could have excessive vaginal discharge during normal conditions like:

  • You can have excess vaginal discharge during ovulation and pregnancy.
  • If you have an object in or near the vagina that shouldn’t be there (like tampons)
  • An irritation or rash caused due to allergic reactions caused by detergents, soaps, sexual lubricants etc.
  • You might have atrophic vaginitis (which can happen after menopause). It is due to a decrease in estrogen levels causing the vagina to become dry and thinner than usual.

Your vaginal discharge could be smelly for many reasons. If your vaginal discharge symptoms like an unpleasant or strong “fishy” odour, it could indicate that you have a vaginal infection. Your vaginal discharge may change colour, get heavier, or smell unusual. You may experience irritation around the vaginal opening. Changes in vaginal discharge may or may not indicate a vaginal infection. If you are unsure, consult your doctor for smelly vaginal discharge treatment.

What medicine can cure discharge?

There are different medicines available depending on your vaginal discharge cause. For conditions like trichomoniasis and bacterial vaginosis, you can treat them using antibiotics. If you have yeast infections, they can be treated using antifungal medications. Hence, if you notice that you are having an unusual vaginal discharge, please consult a doctor for you vaginal discharge treatment.3 

How can I fix my discharge naturally?

There is no natural treatment for vaginal discharge. Vaginal discharge is natural, and you cannot prevent it. However, you can take precautions to limit the risk of infection by taking some precautions. Always keep your vagina clean by washing your vagina gently with water, and avoiding scented products and douches that may irritate your skin. Wearing breathable cotton underwear and thoroughly drying the area can also help. If you are sexually active, you can lower your risk of STIs by using a condom or other barrier method during sexual activity and thoroughly cleaning your sex toys. If you have a period, try to change your tampons and pads regularly.4

Takeaway

So, now you can understand that it is normal to have vaginal discharge. It is how your vagina keeps itself clean and healthy. Changes in the colour, volume, consistency, and smell of your usual vaginal discharge are signs of irregular discharge. Your menstrual cycle may cause changes to your normal vaginal discharge. If you notice any other changes in your vaginal discharge or if it is accompanied by other symptoms such as pain, itching or burning, contact your doctor. You should not use sprays, perfumes, or douches to improve the smell of your vagina.5
